Karontā pāpakaṁ kammaṁ, yaṁ hoti kaṭukapphalaṁ.
verses.translation: Fools of little wit move about with themselves as their own foes, doing evil deeds that bear bitter fruit.
verses.commentary: The greatest enemy is not external but internal. Fools harm themselves more than any enemy could by performing unwholesome actions that will inevitably bring suffering. Through ignorance and lack of wisdom, they become their own worst enemies. This teaches the importance of guarding one's own conduct.

story.title: The Story of Suppasena the Leper
story.content: A leper named Suppasena lived by begging. After hearing the Buddha's teaching, he attained stream-entry. While returning home with joy in his heart, he was attacked and killed by a cow. Though his life ended tragically, he was reborn in a heavenly realm due to his newfound wisdom. The Buddha explained that the cow was his enemy, but ignorance would have been an even greater enemy.

verses.pali:
Na taṁ kammaṁ kataṁ sādhu, yaṁ katvā anutappati;
Yassa assumukho rodaṁ, vipākaṁ paṭisevati.
verses.translation: That deed is not well done which, having been done, brings remorse, whose result one experiences with tears and lamentation.
verses.commentary: This verse provides a practical test for evaluating actions. Wholesome deeds bring peace and joy even in memory, while unwholesome deeds cause regret and anxiety. If an action leads to remorse and suffering when its consequences arrive, it was not a good deed. This encourages reflection before acting.

story.title: The Story of a Farmer
story.content: A farmer, driven by anger, killed his ox. Later, when he needed the animal for plowing, he deeply regretted his hasty action. His fields went unplowed, and he faced financial difficulties. The Buddha used this example to show how evil deeds, done in the heat of passion, lead to regret and suffering.

verses.pali:
Tañca kammaṁ kataṁ sādhu, yaṁ katvā nānutappati;
Yassa patīto sumano, vipākaṁ paṭisevati.
verses.translation: That deed is well done which, having been done, brings no remorse, whose result one experiences with joy and satisfaction.
verses.commentary: This verse presents the opposite - the mark of a wholesome deed. Actions performed with wisdom, compassion, and virtue bring happiness both in the doing and in remembering. When their results ripen, they bring joy rather than sorrow. This provides guidance for ethical conduct.

story.title: The Story of a Generous Devotee
story.content: A lay disciple practiced generosity throughout his life, giving food, shelter, and support to monks and the poor. On his deathbed, he recalled these good deeds with joy and satisfaction, seeing visions of the heavenly realms awaiting him. He died peacefully and was reborn in a deva realm, demonstrating the happiness that follows wholesome actions.

verses.pali:
Madhuvā maññati bālo, yāva pāpaṁ na paccati;
Yadā ca paccati pāpaṁ, atha bālo dukkhaṁ nigacchati.
verses.translation: The fool thinks their evil deed is as sweet as honey, so long as it has not ripened. But when it ripens, then the fool suffers.
verses.commentary: Evil deeds may seem pleasant or profitable at the time of commission, but their karmic consequences inevitably bring suffering. The fool, lacking foresight, is deceived by immediate gratification. Like honey that seems sweet initially but may contain poison, evil actions lead to bitter results. Wisdom means understanding future consequences.

story.title: The Story of a Flower-Seller Woman
story.content: A woman devoted to the Buddha's teaching was invited by another woman to join in slandering a monk. Tempted by friendship, she participated. The slander seemed harmless at first, like sweet conversation. However, as a result of this evil deed, she was reborn in hell for many years, experiencing terrible suffering. Only after that karma was exhausted could she be reborn in better circumstances.

verses.pali:
Māse māse kusaggena, bālo bhuñjeyya bhojanaṁ;
Na so saṅkhātadhammānaṁ, kalaṁ agghati soḷasiṁ.
verses.translation: Month after month a fool may eat food with the tip of a blade of grass, yet they are not worth a sixteenth part of those who have comprehended the Dhamma.
verses.commentary: Extreme asceticism without wisdom is worthless. Even if someone practices severe austerities, eating tiny amounts from a grass blade for years, such practices without understanding the Dhamma have no real value. What matters is wisdom and insight, not mere physical mortification. Right practice must be guided by right understanding.

story.title: The Story of Ascetics
story.content: Some ascetics practiced extreme austerities, eating almost nothing and torturing their bodies. Despite their severe practices, they made no spiritual progress because they lacked right understanding. The Buddha explained that even a fraction of the merit of someone who understands the Dhamma far exceeds the results of such misguided austerities.

verses.pali:
Na hi pāpaṁ kataṁ kammaṁ, sajju khīraṁva muccati;
Ḍahantaṁ bālam anveti, bhasmacchannova pāvako.
verses.translation: An evil deed does not bear fruit immediately, just as milk does not curdle at once. Like fire covered by ashes, it smolders, following the fool until it burns.
verses.commentary: Karmic consequences are not always immediate. Just as fresh milk takes time to sour, and fire hidden under ashes appears dormant yet retains its burning potential, evil deeds lie dormant before manifesting their results. This delay can deceive the fool into thinking they've escaped consequences, but karma eventually ripens.

story.title: The Story of a Snake-Ghost
story.content: A cruel man killed many people during his life without apparent consequence. Only after his death did he experience the full weight of his evil karma, being reborn as a suffering ghost. The Buddha explained that his evil deeds, though seemingly forgotten, were like fire under ashes - they eventually burst into flame, causing immense suffering.

verses.pali:
Yāvadeva anatthāya, ñattaṁ bālassa jāyati;
Hanti bālassa sukkaṁsaṁ, muddham assa vipātayaṁ.
verses.translation: Whatever knowledge the fool acquires only harms them, destroying their good fortune and splitting their head.
verses.commentary: Knowledge without wisdom is dangerous. When a fool gains skills or information, they often use it harmfully - for selfish gain, to deceive others, or to feed their ego. This 'knowledge' destroys whatever merit they have accumulated and leads to their downfall. The 'split head' symbolizes the destruction of their potential for good.

story.title: The Story of Two Thieves
story.content: Two brothers were thieves. One was clever and devised sophisticated schemes, while the other was simple-minded. The clever one's schemes eventually led to his capture and severe punishment, while the simple one, unable to devise complex crimes, committed only minor offenses and received lighter punishment. The Buddha explained that the clever brother's intelligence only increased his suffering.

verses.pali:
Asantaṁ bhāvanam iccheyya, purekkhārañca bhikkhusu;
Āvāsesu ca issariyaṁ, pūjā parakulesu ca.
verses.translation: The fool desires undeserved reputation, precedence among monks, authority in monasteries, and honor from other families.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the foolish monk who seeks external recognition without internal development. Such desires - for fame, rank, power, and worship - are obstacles to spiritual progress. True monasticism involves humility, contentment, and dedication to practice, not the pursuit of worldly honors within a spiritual context.

story.title: The Story of Citta the Householder
story.content: Some monks visiting Citta the householder showed great concern for receiving honor and special treatment. They competed for his attention and offerings. In contrast, a simple forest monk who came later showed no interest in such things. Citta was more impressed by the humble monk's genuine practice than by the status-seeking monks' behavior.

verses.translation: 'Let both householders and monks think that this was done by me; let them follow my commands in all matters, great and small' - such is the fool's thought, and thus their desire and pride increase.
verses.commentary: The fool craves control and recognition, wanting everyone to acknowledge their importance and authority. This attitude, whether in lay or monastic life, stems from ego and leads to increasing pride and desire. True spiritual progress requires the opposite - letting go of the need for recognition and control.

story.title: Continuation of Citta's Story
story.content: The status-seeking monks constantly reminded people of their contributions and expected gratitude and obedience. Their pride grew with each acknowledgment. The humble forest monk, by contrast, performed his duties quietly without seeking recognition. His lack of ego impressed many, while the others' pride eventually led to their downfall.

verses.translation: One is the path leading to worldly gain, another is the path leading to Nibbāna. Understanding this, the monk, a disciple of the Buddha, should not delight in honor but cultivate detachment.
verses.commentary: This verse concludes the chapter by clearly distinguishing between worldly success and spiritual liberation. These are fundamentally different paths with different goals. A true disciple must choose between seeking worldly recognition and pursuing liberation. The wise monk cultivates solitude and detachment rather than pursuing fame and honor.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Vanavasitissa
story.content: Venerable Tissa lived alone in the forest, practicing diligently without seeking recognition. When villagers discovered him and began bringing offerings, he felt uncomfortable with the attention. Rather than enjoying the honor, he moved deeper into the forest to maintain his solitude. The Buddha praised him as one who understood the difference between the path to worldly gain and the path to Nibbāna.

chapters.summary: This chapter describes the qualities of wise persons and emphasizes the importance of associating with noble companions who guide one toward enlightenment.

verses.translation: Should one find a wise person who points out faults and reproves, one should follow such a sage as though he were a revealer of hidden treasure. It is always better, never worse, to cultivate such an association.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes the value of constructive criticism from wise teachers. Just as a guide to hidden treasure is invaluable, so is a wise person who points out our faults. Most people avoid criticism, but the Buddha teaches that those who help us see our shortcomings are precious friends. Following their guidance leads only to improvement.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Rādha
story.content: Rādha was a poor old brahmin who served the monks at Jetavana monastery hoping to be ordained. The monks considered him too old and feeble. When the Buddha learned of this, he asked who had encouraged Rādha to perform meritorious deeds in the past. Finding that no one had, the Buddha personally ordained him. Under the Buddha's guidance and admonition, Rādha attained Arahantship. The Buddha spoke this verse to emphasize the importance of teachers who guide and correct us.

verses.pali:
Ovadeyyānusāseyya, asabbhā ca nivāraye;
Sataṁ hi so piyo hoti, asataṁ hoti appiyo.
verses.translation: Let one advise, instruct, and dissuade from evil. Such a person is dear to the good and detested by the bad.
verses.commentary: Those who give wise counsel and restrain others from evil are naturally loved by virtuous people and disliked by the wicked. The good appreciate guidance because they seek improvement, while the bad resent correction because they don't want to change. This verse encourages us to be willing to advise others despite potential resistance.

story.title: The Story of Monks Assaji and Punabbasukā
story.content: Monks Assaji and Punabbasukā were undisciplined and led other monks astray with frivolous behavior. When well-behaved monks tried to advise them, they became angry and refused to listen. Eventually, their misconduct led to their expulsion from the Sangha. The Buddha explained that good people welcome advice while bad people reject it, illustrating the principle stated in this verse.

verses.pali:
Na bhaje pāpake mitte, na bhaje purisādhame;
Bhajetha mitte kalyāṇe, bhajetha purisuttame.
verses.translation: One should not associate with evil companions, nor with the mean. One should associate with good friends and with the noblest of persons.
verses.commentary: Companionship profoundly affects our character and destiny. Evil companions encourage unwholesome behavior, while noble friends inspire virtue and wisdom. The Buddha repeatedly emphasized the importance of admirable friendship (kalyāṇa-mitta) as essential to spiritual progress. This verse is a clear directive to choose companions wisely.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Channa
story.content: Channa was the Buddha's former charioteer who became a monk but remained arrogant and difficult. He associated with other unruly monks and refused to accept guidance from senior monks. Despite repeated advice, he continued his misconduct. Only after the Buddha's passing, when the Sangha implemented the Brahmadaṇḍa (silence treatment) punishment, did Channa reform. This story illustrates the danger of bad companionship and the importance of associating with the virtuous.

verses.pali:
Dhammapīti sukhaṁ seti, vippasannena cetasā;
Ariyappavedite dhamme, sadā ramati paṇḍito.
verses.translation: One who drinks of the Dhamma lives happily with a tranquil mind. The wise person always delights in the Dhamma made known by the Noble Ones.
verses.commentary: The 'drink' of Dhamma refers to understanding and practicing the Buddha's teachings. This brings a happiness far superior to sensual pleasures - a joy that comes from inner peace and clarity. The wise constantly delight in studying, contemplating, and practicing the Dhamma taught by the Buddha and the Arahants. This joy is independent of external conditions.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Mahākappina
story.content: Venerable Mahākappina, a former king, attained Arahantship shortly after ordination. He was often heard exclaiming 'Aho sukhaṁ! Aho sukhaṁ!' (Oh, what bliss!). Some monks reported this to the Buddha, wondering if Mahākappina was thinking of his former royal pleasures. The Buddha explained that Mahākappina was experiencing the bliss of Nibbāna and delighting in the Dhamma, far superior to any worldly pleasure. This verse was spoken in reference to him.

verses.pali:
Udakaṁ hi nayanti nettikā, usukārā namayanti tejanaṁ;
Dāruṁ namayanti tacchakā, attānaṁ damayanti paṇḍitā.
verses.translation: Irrigators guide water, fletchers straighten arrows, carpenters shape wood; the wise control themselves.
verses.commentary: This verse uses three examples from daily life to illustrate self-mastery. Just as skilled workers shape external materials through effort and technique, the wise shape their own minds and characters through practice. Self-control requires continuous effort, patience, and skillful means. The parallel emphasizes that mental training is as deliberate and systematic as any craft.

story.title: The Story of Novice Paṇḍita
story.content: A seven-year-old boy named Paṇḍita was ordained as a novice. While going on alms round with his teacher, Venerable Sāriputta, he observed irrigators directing water, arrow-makers straightening shafts, and carpenters shaping wood. He thought: 'If these people can control external materials, surely I can control my own mind.' Returning to the monastery, he practiced meditation with great determination and attained Arahantship before his teacher returned with the alms food. The Buddha spoke this verse praising his quick understanding.

verses.pali:
Selo yathā ekaghano, vātena na samīrati;
Evaṁ nindāpasaṁsāsu, na samiñjanti paṇḍitā.
verses.translation: Just as a solid rock is not shaken by the wind, so the wise are not moved by praise or blame.
verses.commentary: The wise remain equanimous in the face of both praise and criticism. Like a massive rock that stands unmoved in storms, they are not elated by flattery nor depressed by condemnation. This equanimity comes from understanding that praise and blame are worldly conditions that naturally arise and pass. The wise person's inner stability does not depend on others' opinions.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Lakundaka Bhaddiya
story.content: Venerable Bhaddiya was extremely short and unattractive. People often made fun of his appearance, and some praised him mockingly. Despite constant ridicule and insincere praise, Bhaddiya remained perfectly calm and undisturbed. He had attained Arahantship and was completely free from concern about his appearance or others' opinions. The Buddha pointed to him as an example of one who remains like a rock, unmoved by praise or blame.

verses.pali:
Yathā pi rahado gambhīro, vippasanno anāvilo;
Evaṁ dhammāni sutvāna, vippasīdanti paṇḍitā.
verses.translation: Just as a deep lake is clear and calm, so the wise become tranquil upon hearing the Dhamma.
verses.commentary: A deep lake remains clear and undisturbed even when streams flow into it. Similarly, when the wise hear the Dhamma, their minds become profoundly peaceful and clear. The teachings don't agitate them but rather bring clarity and stillness. This tranquility comes from understanding the truth and seeing things as they really are.

story.title: The Story of Kāṇamātā
story.content: A woman named Kāṇamātā was devoted to her beautiful daughter. When the daughter died suddenly, she became deranged with grief and wandered about asking everyone where her daughter was. Some people mocked her. When she encountered the Buddha, he gently brought her to awareness and taught her about the nature of death and impermanence. Upon hearing the Dhamma, her mind became calm and clear like a deep, still lake. She attained stream-entry and her grief was replaced by peaceful understanding.

verses.pali:
Sabbattha ve sappurisā cajanti, na kāmakāmā lapayanti santo;
Sukhena phuṭṭhā atha vā dukhena, na uccāvacaṁ paṇḍitā dassayanti.
verses.translation: The good renounce all attachments; the virtuous do not prattle with craving for pleasures. Whether touched by happiness or sorrow, the wise show neither elation nor depression.
verses.commentary: True wise persons have let go of all attachments and don't waste time in idle chatter driven by desire. They maintain equanimity whether experiencing pleasure or pain, neither becoming elated in good times nor depressed in bad times. This even-mindedness reflects deep understanding of impermanence and not-self. They have transcended the eight worldly conditions.

story.title: The Story of Five Hundred Monks
story.content: Five hundred monks were invited by a brahmin to spend the rainy season in his village, but he forgot his invitation and provided no support. The monks had to survive on horse-fodder. Despite this hardship, they remained tranquil and continued their practice without complaint. When conditions improved later, they showed no special joy. The Buddha praised them for maintaining equanimity in both favorable and unfavorable circumstances, illustrating the teaching of this verse.

verses.pali:
Na attahetu na parassa hetu, na puttam icche na dhanaṁ na raṭṭhaṁ;
Na iccheyya adhammena samiddhim attano, sa sīlavā paññavā dhammiko siyā.
verses.translation: Not for one's own sake, nor for the sake of others, should one desire son, wealth, or kingdom through unrighteousness. Such a person would be virtuous, wise, and righteous.
verses.commentary: This verse addresses the question of ends and means. Even desirable goals like family welfare or social prosperity should never be pursued through unethical means. A truly wise person refuses to compromise moral principles even for apparently good outcomes. True virtue means adhering to Dhamma regardless of potential worldly benefits or losses.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Dhammika
story.content: Venerable Dhammika was known for his strict adherence to moral principles. He refused to compromise the Vinaya rules even when doing so might have brought material benefit to the Sangha. Some monks criticized him as too rigid, but the Buddha praised his integrity. The Buddha explained that a true follower of the Dhamma never seeks gain through unrighteous means, whether for oneself or others. Dhammika exemplified this principle of unwavering ethical conduct.

verses.pali:
Appakā te manussesu, ye janā pāragāmino;
Athāyaṁ itarā pajā, tīram evānudhāvati.
verses.translation: Few among people are those who cross to the far shore. The rest of humanity merely runs along this shore.
verses.commentary: The 'far shore' represents Nibbāna, liberation from suffering. Very few people successfully cross the ocean of saṁsāra to reach this goal. Most people remain on 'this shore' of continued birth and death, running back and forth pursuing worldly concerns. This verse emphasizes both the rarity of liberation and the common human tendency to remain trapped in cyclic existence through ignorance.

story.title: The Story of Dhamma Listeners
story.content: A large crowd assembled to hear the Buddha teach. After the discourse, the Buddha surveyed the audience with his divine eye and saw that only a few had attained path and fruition, while the vast majority gained no lasting benefit. Though many heard the Dhamma, few truly understood and practiced it. The Buddha spoke this verse to explain that while many may listen to teachings, only a few actually 'cross over' to liberation.

verses.pali:
Ye ca kho sammadakkhāte, dhamme dhammānuvattino;
Te janā pāram essanti, maccudheyyaṁ suduttaraṁ.
verses.translation: But those who practice according to the well-taught Dhamma will cross beyond the realm of death, so difficult to cross.
verses.commentary: This verse complements the previous one by identifying who reaches the far shore: those who practice the Dhamma as taught. Mere intellectual knowledge is insufficient; one must live according to the teachings. The 'realm of death' (maccudheyyaṁ) refers to the entire cycle of birth and death. Though extremely difficult to transcend, it can be crossed through diligent practice of the Dhamma.

story.title: Continuation of Dhamma Listeners Story
story.content: Among the crowd that heard the Buddha teach, those who took the Dhamma to heart and practiced it earnestly did cross beyond the realm of death. Some attained stream-entry, others once-returning or non-returning, and a few even attained Arahantship. The Buddha explained that these individuals succeeded not merely because they heard the teaching, but because they practiced according to what they heard. Their diligence led them across the ocean of saṁsāra.

verses.pali:
Kaṇhaṁ dhammaṁ vippahāya, sukkaṁ bhāvetha paṇḍito;
Okā anokam āgamma, viveke yattha dūramaṁ.
verses.translation: The wise person should abandon dark ways and cultivate the bright, having gone from home to homelessness, to seclusion so difficult to enjoy.
verses.commentary: This verse specifically addresses those who renounce household life for monastic practice. 'Dark ways' refer to unwholesome states and actions, while 'bright' refers to wholesome ones. The journey from home (worldly life) to homelessness (monastic life) to seclusion (meditative solitude) is progressively difficult but leads to liberation. Few find joy in such seclusion, but the wise cultivate it.

story.title: The Story of Five Hundred Visiting Monks
story.content: Five hundred monks from various regions came to pay respects to the Buddha. After receiving meditation instructions, they practiced diligently in the forest. They abandoned all unwholesome states and cultivated wholesome ones through intensive meditation in seclusion. Despite the difficulties of solitary practice, they persevered and all attained Arahantship. The Buddha spoke these verses praising their achievement.

verses.pali:
Tatrābhiratim iccheyya, hitvā kāme akiñcano;
Pariyodapeyya attānaṁ, cittaklesehi paṇḍito.
verses.translation: There he should wish to find delight, free from sensual desires, possessing nothing. The wise person should purify himself from mental defilements.
verses.commentary: Continuing the theme of renunciation, this verse describes the ideal state of one who has left home. Such a person should find joy in solitude, be free from sensual craving, own nothing, and work to purify the mind from all defilements. This purification is the essential work of the renunciant. External renunciation must be accompanied by internal purification.

story.title: Continuation of Five Hundred Monks
story.content: The five hundred monks who attained Arahantship found genuine delight in their forest seclusion. They had abandoned all sensual desires and attachment to possessions. Through meditation, they systematically purified their minds from greed, hatred, delusion, and all other mental defilements. Their joy in solitude was complete because they had achieved inner purity. They exemplified the ideal described in this verse.

verses.translation: Those who have fully developed their minds in the factors of enlightenment, who delight in relinquishment and non-clinging, whose taints are destroyed and who are radiant - they have attained Nibbāna in this very life.
verses.commentary: This concluding verse describes Arahants who have perfected the seven factors of enlightenment (mindfulness, investigation, energy, joy, tranquility, concentration, and equanimity). They delight in letting go rather than in acquiring. Having destroyed all mental taints (āsava), they shine with wisdom and have realized Nibbāna while still living. This is the ultimate achievement of the wise person.

story.title: The Final Achievement
story.content: The five hundred monks who practiced diligently developed all seven enlightenment factors fully. They delighted in releasing all attachments rather than in gaining anything. Having destroyed all āsavas (taints of sensual desire, becoming, views, and ignorance), they became radiant with the light of wisdom. Though still alive, they had attained Nibbāna - complete liberation from suffering. The Buddha spoke this final verse of the chapter to describe their perfect attainment.

chapters.summary: This chapter details the qualities of Arahants—those who have achieved complete enlightenment and liberation from all suffering and attachments.

verses.pali:
Gataddhino visokassa, vippamuttassa sabbadhi;
Sabbaganthappahīnassa, parilāho na vijjati.
verses.translation: For one who has completed the journey, who is free from sorrow, who is wholly liberated in every way, who has abandoned all fetters - for such a one there is no fever of passion.
verses.commentary: This opening verse describes the Arahant who has reached the end of the spiritual journey. Having completed the path, they are free from sorrow, completely liberated, and have cut all fetters that bind beings to existence. The 'fever' (parilāha) of passion, which torments ordinary beings, no longer exists for them. They have achieved perfect peace.

story.title: The Question of Jīvaka
story.content: The physician Jīvaka asked the Buddha whether Arahants experience physical pain. The Buddha explained that while Arahants may experience physical discomfort, they experience no mental anguish or 'fever' of passion. Their minds remain completely at peace regardless of bodily conditions. The Buddha spoke this verse to clarify the difference between unavoidable physical sensations and the mental suffering that has been completely eliminated in Arahants.

verses.pali:
Uyyuñjanti satīmanto, na nikete ramanti te;
Haṁsā va pallalaṁ hitvā, okamokaṁ jahanti te.
verses.translation: The mindful ones exert themselves. They are not attached to any abode. Like swans that abandon a lake, they leave home after home behind.
verses.commentary: Arahants maintain constant mindfulness and energy. They don't become attached to any dwelling place or situation. The simile of swans leaving lakes emphasizes their non-attachment - just as swans move freely from one body of water to another without clinging, Arahants move through life without attachment to places, people, or possessions.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Mahākassapa
story.content: Venerable Mahākassapa was known for his practice of dwelling in remote forests and his constant mindfulness. Before the end of one rainy season retreat, the Buddha announced they would soon be leaving. While other monks rushed to prepare, Mahākassapa calmly made ready, showing no attachment to the place. Throughout his life, he moved from place to place without clinging to any dwelling. The Buddha praised his non-attachment and spoke this verse about those who, like swans, leave one place for another without attachment.

verses.translation: Those who do not hoard, who understand the nature of food, whose sphere is the liberation that is void and signless - their path, like that of birds through the sky, cannot be traced.
verses.commentary: Arahants don't accumulate possessions or mental states. They understand food not as something enjoyable but as mere sustenance for the body. Their meditation object is the void (suññata) and signless (animitta) liberation - Nibbāna beyond all conceptual elaboration. Their mental states cannot be tracked, just as birds leave no trail in the sky. They have transcended conventional existence.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Bellaṭṭhasīsa
story.content: Venerable Bellaṭṭhasīsa collected alms food and stored it so he could spend days in uninterrupted meditation. Some monks criticized this as hoarding. When questioned, he explained his motivation was purely for extended practice, not attachment. However, after hearing this teaching, he stopped storing food and relied only on daily alms. He understood food simply as fuel for practice and developed the void and signless liberation. His practice became so refined that his movements left no 'trace' in terms of creating new karma.

verses.translation: One whose taints are destroyed, who is not attached to food, whose sphere is liberation that is void and signless - their track, like that of birds through the sky, cannot be traced.
verses.commentary: This verse is similar to the previous one but emphasizes the destruction of āsavas (mental taints). An Arahant has completely eliminated the taints of sensual desire, desire for existence, wrong views, and ignorance. Free from these taints and unattached even to food, dwelling in the void and signless liberation, their path through life leaves no karmic trace.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Anuruddha
story.content: Venerable Anuruddha once searched through a rubbish heap for cloth to make a robe. Jālinī, a devī who had been his wife in a previous life, offered him celestial cloth out of concern. He accepted three pieces but remained completely unattached. His āsavas had been destroyed, and he viewed the cloth and food with complete equanimity. Like a bird flying through the sky, he moved through life creating no new karma. The Buddha praised his complete non-attachment despite engaging with material necessities.

verses.pali:
Yass'indriyāni samathaṅgatāni, assā yathā sārathinā sudantā;
Pahīnamānassa anāsavassa, devā'pi tassa pihayanti tādino.
verses.translation: One whose senses are calmed like horses well-tamed by a charioteer, who has abandoned pride and is free from taints - even the devas cherish such a steadfast one.
verses.commentary: The senses are compared to powerful horses that can pull a chariot in any direction. The Arahant has completely tamed the senses through mindfulness and wisdom, just as a skilled charioteer controls horses. Having abandoned all conceit and destroyed all taints, such a person is admired even by celestial beings. The gods themselves envy the attainments of human Arahants.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Mahākaccāyana
story.content: At the end of a rainy season retreat, the Buddha was receiving visitors at Pubbārāma monastery. Sakka (Indra), king of the gods, arrived with a large retinue of devas to pay respects. A seat was reserved for Venerable Mahākaccāyana, who arrived late from Avanti. When he entered, all the devas rose respectfully. Sakka explained that he and all the devas revered Mahākaccāyana for his perfect sense control, freedom from conceit, and destruction of all taints. The Buddha confirmed that even celestial beings honor such accomplished Arahants.

verses.pali:
Paṭhavisamo no virujjhati, indakhilūpamo tādi subbato;
Rahado va apetakaddamo, saṁsārā na bhavanti tādino.
verses.translation: Like the earth, one who is settled does not show resentment. Like a pillar firmly set, one who is steadfast and well-disciplined does not waver. Like a lake cleared of mud, for such a one there are no more rounds of rebirth.
verses.commentary: This verse uses three similes to describe the Arahant. Like the earth that receives both pure and impure without reaction, the Arahant accepts all experiences with equanimity. Like a firmly planted pillar (indakhīla), they remain unmoved by worldly conditions. Like a clear lake free from mud, their mind is pure, and they have no more rebirths. The stability and purity described here characterize complete liberation.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Sāriputta
story.content: Venerable Sāriputta was once verbally abused by a brahmin for an extended period. Throughout the tirade, Sāriputta remained completely calm, showing no sign of anger or disturbance. His equanimity was like the earth that remains unmoved whether people toss flowers or filth upon it. Even when the brahmin later apologized, Sāriputta showed no special reaction, having already been completely unperturbed by the abuse. The Buddha praised his steadfastness and spoke this verse describing such perfect equanimity.

verses.pali:
Santaṁ tassa manaṁ hoti, santā vācā ca kamma ca;
Sammadaññā vimuttassa, upasantassa tādino.
verses.translation: Calm is the mind, calm the speech and action of one who is freed through perfect knowledge, who is completely peaceful and equipoised.
verses.commentary: The Arahant exhibits perfect calm in all three spheres: mind, speech, and bodily action. This calmness arises naturally from liberation through perfect knowledge (sammadañña) - direct realization of the Four Noble Truths. Being completely at peace (upasanta) and equipoised (tādin), their entire being radiates tranquility. This is not mere external composure but the natural expression of internal liberation.

story.title: The Story of a Novice from Kosambi
story.content: A young novice monk from Kosambi attained Arahantship through diligent practice. Afterwards, his entire demeanor reflected perfect calm. His teacher and other monks noticed that his mind, speech, and actions had become extraordinarily peaceful and controlled. Even in challenging situations, he remained perfectly composed. When questions arose about his transformation, the Buddha explained that he had attained liberation through perfect knowledge, and this naturally manifested as complete calmness in all aspects of his being.

verses.pali:
Assaddho akataññū ca, sandhicchedo ca yo naro;
Hatāvakāso vantāso, sa ve uttamaporiso.
verses.translation: The person who has no need for faith (having direct knowledge), who understands the unconditioned, who has severed all connections, who has destroyed all opportunities (for rebirth), who has expelled all desire - that person is truly supreme.
verses.commentary: This verse describes the Arahant through six characteristics. They don't need faith (assaddha) because they have direct knowledge. They understand the 'unmade' (akata) - Nibbāna. They have cut the connection (sandhiccheda) to continued existence. They have destroyed opportunities (hatāvakāsa) for rebirth. They have expelled (vantāsa) all desire. Such a person is the highest of humans (uttamaporisa).

story.title: Another Account of Venerable Sāriputta
story.content: Venerable Sāriputta exemplified all these qualities. He had direct knowledge of truth, not mere faith. He had realized the unconditioned Nibbāna. He had severed all connections to future rebirth. No opportunities for creating new karma remained. All desires had been completely expelled from his mind. The Buddha declared that Sāriputta represented the supreme person (uttamaporisa), having fulfilled all the qualities of an Arahant. Other monks should aspire to such complete liberation.

verses.pali:
Gāme vā yadi vāraññe, ninne vā yadi vā thale;
Yattha arahanto viharanti, taṁ bhūmiṁ rāmaṇeyyakaṁ.
verses.translation: Whether in village or in forest, whether in valley or on hill - wherever Arahants dwell, that place is delightful.
verses.commentary: The presence of Arahants makes any location pleasant. This is not due to physical features of the place but to the peaceful, pure presence of liberated beings. Their spiritual radiance affects the environment. Moreover, from their own perspective, having transcended attachment, all places are equally acceptable. They bring delight to any location rather than seeking delight from locations.

story.title: The Story of Venerable Revata
story.content: Revata was the youngest brother of the Chief Disciple, Sariputta. He was only seven years old when his parents arranged a marriage for him. At the wedding reception, he met an old lady who was one hundred and twenty years old, and he realized that all beings are subject to ageing and decay. So he ran away and went to a monastery where he was made a samanera. He took a meditation subject and left for an acacia forest thirty yojanas away. At the end of the vassa, he attained arahatship. The Buddha accompanied by Thera Sariputta and five hundred other bhikkhus set out to visit him. The journey was long and rough, but the devas looked to all their needs. Revata created special monasteries by supernormal power. On their return, they came to Visakha's house, who offered them alms-food. After the meal, Visakha asked the Buddha if the place of Revata in the acacia forest was pleasant. The Buddha answered with this verse, explaining that wherever Arahants dwell, that place is delightful.

verses.pali:
Ramaṇīyāni araññāni, yattha na ramatī jano;
Vītarāgā ramissanti, na te kāmagavesino.
verses.translation: Delightful are the forests where worldlings find no pleasure. There the passionless will rejoice, for they seek no sensual pleasures.
verses.commentary: This concluding verse of the Arahanta Vagga contrasts the perspectives of worldly people and Arahants. Ordinary people find no joy in remote forests because such places offer no sensual pleasures or entertainment. However, those who are free from passion (vītarāga) - the Arahants - delight in such secluded places precisely because they are conducive to meditation and peace. Arahants do not seek sensual pleasures (kāma), so the absence of worldly attractions is no disadvantage to them. Instead, the quiet and solitude of forests provide ideal conditions for dwelling in the peace of Nibbāna. This verse emphasizes how liberation transforms one's relationship with the environment - what appears unattractive to those bound by craving becomes delightful to those who are free.

story.title: The Story of a Woman
story.content: A monk was meditating in a pleasure park. A woman had arranged to meet a man there, but he did not turn up. As she was looking for him, she saw the meditating monk and tried to seduce him. The elder became aroused, but the Buddha, seeing the situation with his Divine Eye, projected himself before the monk and spoke this verse, commenting on the attractiveness of the forests where the passionless dwell. Upon hearing the Buddha's words, the monk's mind became clear and he attained Arahantship. Having achieved liberation, he now understood firsthand the truth of the verse - that forests are indeed delightful to those free from passion, who do not seek sensual pleasures.

chapters.summary: This chapter emphasizes quality over quantity in spiritual practice, showing that one meaningful word, verse, or moment of understanding is worth more than thousands of meaningless ones. It also teaches that self-conquest is the greatest victory and that honoring the virtuous brings great blessings.

verses.pali:
Sahassamapi ce vācā, anatthapadasaṁhitā;
Ekaṁ atthapadaṁ seyyo, yaṁ sutvā upasammati.
verses.translation: Better than a thousand sayings, comprising useless words, is a single beneficial word, by hearing which one is pacified.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes that the value of words lies not in their quantity but in their quality and benefit. A thousand meaningless words are worthless compared to one word that brings understanding and peace. True wisdom comes from beneficial teachings that lead to tranquility of mind, not from empty verbosity. The Buddha valued concise, meaningful instruction that actually transforms the listener's mind.

story.title: The Story of Tambadāṭhika the Executioner
story.content: A bloodthirsty villain named Tambadāṭhika joined a band of robbers and committed many crimes. When the robbers were caught and sentenced to death, no one was willing to execute them. The judges offered to spare the life of any robber who would execute all the others. Only Tambadāṭhika volunteered. His life was spared, and he became the public executioner. On the day he was to die, he was about to start his breakfast when he saw the Elder Sāriputta walking for alms. He thought, 'I have done many evil deeds, I should make merit by offering rice gruel to this monk.' He invited the elder, offered the gruel, and stood fanning him. Seeing that the man was famished, the elder told him to eat and called someone else to fan him. Then he taught him the Dhamma. Unable to concentrate due to remorse, the executioner was troubled. The elder skillfully questioned him about whether he had wished to kill all those people, or whether another had made him do it. He replied that the king made him do it. The elder asked, 'In that case, what evil have you done?' This relieved his guilt enough for him to concentrate on the Dhamma talk. He gained a high stage of insight knowledge and died that same day, being reborn in the Tuṣita heaven. The Buddha explained that his fortunate rebirth was due to the excellent, beneficial advice of the Elder Sāriputta - one meaningful teaching that brought him peace.

verses.pali:
Sahassamapi ce gāthā, anatthapadasaṁhitā;
Ekaṁ gāthāpadaṁ seyyo, yaṁ sutvā upasammati.
verses.translation: Better than a thousand verses, comprising useless words, is a single beneficial line, by hearing which one is pacified.
verses.commentary: Similar to the previous verse, this emphasizes that memorizing or reciting numerous verses without understanding their meaning brings no benefit. One line of verse that is truly understood and brings peace to the mind is infinitely more valuable. This teaching counters the tendency to value quantity of learning over genuine understanding and transformation. The Buddha taught for liberation, not for intellectual accumulation.

story.title: The Story of Bāhiya Dārucīriya
story.content: A ship-wreck victim swam to the shore at the port of Suppāraka and saved himself. Having lost his clothes, he covered himself with bark (Dārucīriya). The locals thought he was an Arahant, and because of their adulation, he came to believe it himself. In a former life, Bāhiya had been one of seven monks who isolated themselves on a mountain ledge attempting to attain the goal. The eldest attained Arahantship and the second attained Non-returning, but Bāhiya and four others died in the attempt. The second monk, reborn in the Brahma realm, saw Bāhiya's plight and came to advise him that he was not an Arahant. He told him the true Arahant, the Buddha, was dwelling at Sāvatthī. At once, Bāhiya set off and with celestial help arrived the next morning while the Buddha was on his alms-round. Bāhiya repeatedly requested the Dhamma teaching. Seeing that his mind was now equanimous, the Buddha taught him: 'Bāhiya, train yourself like this — when you see something, just know that you see it; when you hear something, just know that you hear it. When, Bāhiya, for you in the seen is merely what is seen, in the known is merely the known, then you will not be with that. When you are not with that, then you will not be in that. When you are not in that, then you will be neither here, nor beyond, nor in between. Just this is the end of suffering.' As the Buddha was teaching this brief Dhamma, the mind of Bāhiya was freed from all defilements. Shortly afterwards, Bāhiya was gored to death by a cow. The Buddha told the monks to cremate his body and build a stūpa as Bāhiya had attained Arahantship through just a few meaningful verses.

verses.pali:
Yo ca gāthāsataṁ bhāse, anatthapadasaṁhitā;
Ekaṁ dhammapadaṁ seyyo, yaṁ sutvā upasammati.
verses.translation: Though one recites a hundred verses of meaningless words, better is a single true word, by hearing which one is pacified.
verses.commentary: This verse continues the theme, specifically emphasizing 'Dhammapadaṁ' - a word of Dhamma or truth. One hundred verses without meaning or application are worthless compared to a single word of truth that transforms the mind. The Buddha's teaching is practical and results-oriented - what matters is not scholarly accumulation but actual peace and liberation achieved through understanding truth.

story.title: Continuation of Bāhiya's Story
story.content: This verse was also spoken in reference to Bāhiya Dārucīriya, whose story illustrates perfectly how one word of Dhamma - the Buddha's brief teaching on non-attachment to sense experiences - brought complete liberation. Bāhiya could have spent years studying hundreds of verses, but instead, through just a few meaningful lines of true Dhamma teaching, he attained Arahantship immediately. The Buddha used Bāhiya's story to teach the monks about the supreme value of understanding even a single line of genuine Dhamma over memorizing countless meaningless verses.

verses.pali:
Yo sahassaṁ sahassena, saṅgāme mānuse jine;
Ekañca jeyya attānaṁ, sa ve saṅgāmajuttamo.
verses.translation: Though one should conquer a million men in battle, yet he is the noblest victor who has conquered himself.
verses.commentary: This verse shifts from the theme of quality over quantity in learning to quality in achievement. Conquering a million enemies in battle appears impressive, but conquering oneself - one's own defilements, passions, and negative tendencies - is the supreme victory. External conquests are temporary and often bring more suffering, while self-conquest brings lasting peace and liberation. The Buddha redefines heroism and victory in spiritual terms.

story.title: The Story of the Elder Nun Kuṇḍalakesī
story.content: A millionaire's daughter fell in love with a robber. Her parents paid for his release, and she married him. He later took his wife to a cliff intending to rob and kill her. She pleaded for her life to no avail. Pretending to embrace him one last time, she pushed him off the cliff. Fearing to return home, she became a nun with wandering ascetics. She soon mastered a thousand verses and toured the country defeating all-comers in debate, becoming known as Jambuparibbājikā from her custom of challenging others by planting a Rose-apple branch. When she came to Sāvatthī and set up her challenge branch, the Elder Sāriputta had some boys trample it. When she met him, he could answer all her questions, but then put one she couldn't answer: 'What is the one?' He told her she would have to enter the Order to learn the answer. She became a nun and attained Arahantship with analytical knowledge within just a few days. The monks discussed how she had defeated a robber and then, on hearing a few words of the Dhamma, had become an Arahant. The Buddha spoke these verses on the efficacy of words of truth and the supreme importance of self-conquest. Though she had conquered a dangerous robber and defeated many in debate, her greatest victory was conquering herself.

verses.pali:
Attā have jitaṁ seyyo, yā cāyaṁ itarā pajā;
Attadantassa posassa, niccaṁ saññatacārino.
verses.translation: Self-conquest is far greater than the conquest of others; neither a deity nor a gandhabba, nor Māra with Brahmā, can overturn the victory of one who is self-possessed and restrained.
verses.commentary: This verse continues the theme of self-conquest, emphasizing its permanence. Unlike worldly victories that can be reversed, the victory over oneself is absolute and irreversible. Even the most powerful celestial beings cannot undo the achievement of someone who has conquered their own mind and lives with constant restraint. This victory is internal, independent of external circumstances, and therefore unassailable.

story.title: The Story of the Gambler
story.content: A Brahmin who made his living through gambling came to the Buddha and asked about the causes of loss. The Buddha replied: 'Sleeping until sunrise, habitual idleness, being wrathful, addiction to alcohol, sexual misconduct, and associating with evil companions - these six things lead to loss.' Then, knowing the Brahmin's motivation for asking, the Buddha asked him how he earned his living. When he replied that it was by gambling, which resulted in both gain and loss, the Buddha explained that neither material gain nor defeating opponents in games brought true victory. The best and most lasting victory was self-conquest - overcoming one's own greed, anger, and delusion. The Buddha spoke this verse to show that while the gambler might sometimes win against others, he remained enslaved to his own passions and thus was truly defeated. Only by conquering himself could he achieve a victory that no one, not even the gods, could overturn.

verses.pali:
Neva devo na gandhabbo, na māro saha brahmunā;
Jitaṁ apajitaṁ kayirā, tathārūpassa jantuno.
verses.translation: Neither a deity nor a gandhabba, nor Māra with Brahmā, can overturn the victory of one who is self-subdued and ever lives in restraint.
verses.commentary: This verse essentially completes the thought of the previous verse, reiterating that the victory of self-conquest is permanent and cannot be undone by any power, whether divine or demonic. Once the mind is truly subdued through self-discipline and the defilements are conquered, this achievement stands forever. It represents the ultimate security - freedom that cannot be taken away by any external force.

story.title: Continuation of the Gambler's Story
story.content: After hearing the Buddha's teaching about self-conquest, the gambler reflected deeply on his life. He realized that no matter how many games he won or how much wealth he accumulated through gambling, he remained a slave to his own greed and the thrill of gaming. His victories were always temporary and could be reversed in the next game. But the Buddha was teaching about a victory that, once achieved, could never be lost - the conquest of one's own defilements. Inspired by this teaching, the gambler decided to give up gambling and pursue the path of self-mastery taught by the Buddha. The Buddha confirmed that this was true wisdom, for a victory over oneself is the only victory that stands forever, immune to reversal by any force in the universe.

verses.translation: Though month after month with a thousand, one should make offerings for a hundred years, if just for a moment one honors one who has perfected himself, that is better than a century of sacrifice.
verses.commentary: This verse teaches the supreme value of honoring those who have perfected themselves - the Arahants. Making lavish monthly offerings for a hundred years cannot compare to even a moment's sincere respect offered to an enlightened being. This is because material offerings, however generous, have limited spiritual benefit, while honoring the enlightened connects one with the highest spiritual qualities and generates immense merit. The Buddha shifts emphasis from ritualistic giving to honoring genuine spiritual achievement.

story.title: The Story of the Elder Sāriputta's Uncle
story.content: The Elder Sāriputta's maternal uncle was a devoted Brahmin who made monthly donations to naked ascetics, hoping through these sacrifices to be reborn in the Brahma realm. He gave generously and consistently, believing that the quantity and regularity of his offerings would secure his desired rebirth. The Elder Sāriputta, seeing his uncle's sincere but misguided efforts, approached him and gently explained that neither he nor his teachers actually knew the true path to the Brahma realm. What they taught was based on speculation and tradition, not on direct knowledge. The Elder Sāriputta then took his uncle to meet the Buddha. The Buddha taught him that a hundred years of such offerings to those who had not perfected themselves could not equal even a brief moment of honoring someone who had actually achieved enlightenment. The Buddha explained the proper path to the Brahma realm and higher spiritual attainments. The uncle, understanding the vast difference between ritual offerings and genuine spiritual practice, became a devoted follower of the Buddha and directed his offerings to those who had truly perfected themselves through practice.

verses.translation: Though for a century one tends the sacred fire in the forest, if only for a moment one honors one who has perfected himself — that honor is better than a century of fire-sacrifice.
verses.commentary: This verse specifically addresses fire-sacrifice, a central practice in Brahmanical tradition. The Buddha taught that tending the sacred fire for a hundred years cannot match a moment's honor given to an enlightened being. External rituals, however ancient or elaborate, cannot compete with honoring one who has achieved internal purification. This was a radical teaching that challenged the prevailing religious orthodoxy of fire-sacrifice and ritual worship.

story.title: The Story of the Elder Sāriputta's Nephew
story.content: The Elder Sāriputta's nephew was a devout Brahmin who followed the traditional practice of fire-sacrifice. Every month, he would sacrifice an animal to tend the sacrificial fire, believing this would lead to rebirth in the Brahma realm. He devoted enormous effort to maintaining the sacred fire and performing the prescribed rituals exactly as taught by his teachers. The Elder Sāriputta, concerned for his nephew's spiritual welfare, went to visit him. He gently explained that neither his nephew nor his teachers actually possessed direct knowledge of the path to the Brahma realm. Their practices were based on tradition and belief, not on personal realization. The Elder took his nephew to meet the Buddha, who taught him that a century spent tending the sacred fire could not equal a moment spent honoring someone who had truly perfected themselves through the Buddha's teaching. The Buddha explained that external fire-rituals, while they might generate some merit, could never match the merit of honoring one who had extinguished the fires of greed, hatred, and delusion within themselves. The nephew, deeply moved by this teaching and recognizing its profound truth, abandoned his fire-sacrifices and became a devoted follower of the Buddha, seeking to purify his own mind rather than tending external fires.

verses.pali:
Yaṁ kiñci yiṭṭhaṁ va hutaṁ va loke, saṁvaccharaṁ yajetha puññapekkho;
Sabbampi taṁ na catubhāgameti, abhivādanā ujjugatesu seyyo.
verses.translation: In this world whatever gift or alms a person seeking merit should offer for a year, all that is not worth a quarter of the reverence towards the upright which is excellent.
verses.commentary: This verse makes an even stronger statement: all the gifts and offerings one could make for an entire year don't equal even one-fourth of the merit gained from showing reverence to the virtuous. The Buddha consistently taught that internal qualities surpass external actions in value. Respecting and learning from those who embody virtue and wisdom generates far more spiritual benefit than any amount of material giving. This teaching encouraged his followers to seek out and honor genuine spiritual practitioners.

story.title: The Story of the Elder Sāriputta's Friend
story.content: The Elder Sāriputta had a close friend from his youth who had become wealthy and devoted himself to making elaborate annual sacrificial offerings. Every year, he would organize a grand sacrificial ceremony, slaughtering many animals and distributing gifts to Brahmins, believing this would generate great merit and secure a favorable rebirth. He spent enormous sums on these annual festivals and took great pride in their scale and magnificence. The Elder Sāriputta, remembering their friendship and concerned for his friend's spiritual welfare, decided to visit him. He found his friend busily preparing for yet another grand sacrifice. The Elder gently suggested that there might be a better way to generate merit. His friend was skeptical - how could anything surpass the merit of his grand annual sacrifices? The Elder took him to meet the Buddha. The Buddha taught him that all his year-long offerings and sacrifices did not equal even one-fourth of the merit gained from showing genuine reverence to those who had perfected themselves in virtue and wisdom. The Buddha explained that while material offerings had their place, they paled in comparison to the spiritual benefit of honoring and learning from the truly virtuous. The friend, deeply impressed by the Buddha's wisdom and recognizing the superficiality of his ritualistic approach, became a devoted follower. He redirected his resources from animal sacrifices to supporting the Sangha and, more importantly, devoted himself to cultivating virtue and wisdom in his own life.

verses.pali:
Abhivādanasīlissa, niccaṁ vuḍḍhāpacāyino;
Cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti, āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṁ balaṁ.
verses.translation: For one who constantly honors and respects the elders, four blessings increase — long-life, beauty, bliss, and strength.
verses.commentary: This verse teaches the concrete benefits of respecting elders and those worthy of respect. Four specific blessings naturally flow to those who maintain an attitude of reverence: longevity, physical beauty and radiance, happiness, and strength. These aren't magical rewards but natural results - respectful people avoid conflicts, maintain peaceful relationships, learn from the wisdom of others, and live harmoniously. The Buddha taught that virtue brings happiness even in this life, and respect for the worthy is a fundamental virtue.

story.title: The Story of Āyuvaḍḍhana - Increase of Life
story.content: Two ascetics lived as companions depending on the city of Dīghalaṅghika. After forty-eight years of practice together, one returned to household life, married, and started a family. When his son was born, he visited his former companion to pay respects and receive a blessing. The ascetic blessed him and his wife with the words 'Long-life to you,' but he did not bless the newborn son. When asked why, the ascetic said that the boy would die within seven days, but suggested that the recluse Gotama might know how to prevent it. The anxious father took his son to the Buddha, who could see the child's past kamma that would lead to his death. However, the Buddha, in his compassion, devised a plan. He instructed the father to erect a pavilion at the door of his house and invite the monks to recite the Protection Discourses continuously for seven days and nights. During this time, the father and his family showed utmost respect and reverence to the monks, serving them with devotion. On the seventh day, the Buddha himself came to recite the texts. On the morning of the eighth day, the danger had passed. The Buddha blessed the child with long life, saying he would live for one hundred and twenty years, and the boy was named Āyuvaḍḍhana - 'increase of life.' When the monks discussed how the child gained long life through the Buddha's compassion, the Buddha spoke this verse, explaining that it was actually the family's respectful service and honoring of the virtuous monks that generated the merit to overcome the child's negative kamma. The four blessings of long life, beauty, happiness, and strength naturally increased for those who constantly honored the worthy with sincerity.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṁ jīve, dussīlo asamāhito;
Ekāhaṁ jīvitaṁ seyyo, sīlavantassa jhāyino.
verses.translation: Though one lives a hundred years, immoral and uncontrolled, better is a single day's life if one is moral and meditative.
verses.commentary: This begins a series of verses (110-115) emphasizing that the quality of life matters far more than its length. A hundred years lived immorally and without mental discipline is worse than a single day lived virtuously and meditatively. The Buddha taught that life's value comes not from duration but from ethical conduct and spiritual development. One day lived well, with morality and meditation, surpasses decades of heedless living because it leads toward liberation rather than further bondage.

story.title: The Story of Novice Saṁkicca
story.content: Thirty men became monks in their old age and wished to retire to a forest to meditate. Foreseeing danger, the Buddha advised them to take the young novice Saṁkicca with them for protection. They were puzzled but obeyed. A band of thieves, learning of the monks' presence in the forest, approached them and demanded that a monk be given as a human sacrifice to their deity. All the elder monks volunteered to offer their lives, but Saṁkicca, though just a novice, obtained their permission to sacrifice his life for the sake of the others, explaining this was why the Buddha had sent him. The bandits took him to their lair and prepared to kill him. The novice entered jhāna, and his mind became so powerful and peaceful that when the ringleader tried to execute him with his sword, it bounced off his neck. He tried again, but his sword shattered. Terrified and amazed, the bandit prostrated himself, begged forgiveness, listened to the Dhamma, and asked to become a monk. All the bandits followed suit. The novice gave them the going-forth and returned to inform the other monks, who were still meditating peacefully in the forest. He took his disciples to the Buddha and related what had happened. The Buddha spoke this verse, explaining that though the young novice had lived only a short time, his life of virtue and meditation was worth more than a hundred years lived immorally and without control. Saṁkicca's one day of perfect virtue and meditation had saved many lives and led to the conversion of an entire band of robbers, while a hundred years lived immorally would have brought only suffering.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṁ jīve, duppañño asamāhito;
Ekāhaṁ jīvitaṁ seyyo, paññavantassa jhāyino.
verses.translation: Though one lives a hundred years, unwise and uncomposed, better is a single day's life if one is wise and meditative.
verses.commentary: This verse continues the theme, emphasizing wisdom (paññā) and meditation (jhāna). Living a century without wisdom and mental composure is worthless compared to a single day lived with genuine understanding and meditative development. The Buddha taught that wisdom - seeing things as they truly are - combined with mental cultivation through meditation represents the essence of valuable human life. Without these qualities, however long we live, we remain in ignorance and suffering.

story.title: The Story of Tree-stump Koṇḍañña
story.content: A monk who had attained Arahantship in a forest was traveling to see the Buddha. Tired from his journey, he sat on a flat rock to rest and entered jhāna meditation. That night, a large group of thieves who had plundered a village came to the same spot carrying their stolen goods. In the darkness, they mistook the meditating elder for a tree stump and piled all their loot over his head before lying down to sleep. At dawn, when they awoke and saw it was actually a monk sitting in meditation, they were terrified, thinking he might be a non-human spirit or deity. The elder calmly told them not to be alarmed and explained that he was merely a monk practicing meditation. The thieves were astounded by his composure and unshakeable peace. They fell at his feet asking forgiveness for their disrespect. The elder taught them the Dhamma, and they were so moved by his wisdom and the peace evident in his meditation that they asked him to give them ordination. He ordained all of them on the spot and brought them to the Buddha. When the monks heard this story, they marveled at how these thieves, who had lived many years in wickedness, were transformed in a single encounter with a wise and meditative monk. The Buddha spoke this verse to explain that the elder's one day of life - lived with wisdom and meditation so profound that he remained unmoved even when thieves piled stolen goods on his head - was worth more than a hundred years lived foolishly and without mental cultivation. This is why he became known as Tree-stump Koṇḍañña, and his single day of wisdom and meditation had transformed an entire band of criminals into monks on the path to liberation.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṁ jīve, kusīto hīnavīriyo;
Ekāhaṁ jīvitaṁ seyyo, vīriyamārabhato daḷhaṁ.
verses.translation: Though one should live a hundred years idle and inactive, better is a single day's life if one makes an intense effort.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes energy (vīriya) and effort. A life of laziness and weak effort, however long, is inferior to a single day of vigorous, determined striving. The Buddha consistently taught that liberation requires sustained effort and energy. Spiritual progress doesn't happen through passive waiting or wishful thinking but through active, determined practice. One day of genuine effort surpasses years of laziness because it moves one toward liberation while laziness keeps one stuck in suffering.

story.title: The Story of the Snake-Slave Elder
story.content: A son of a reputable family in Sāvatthī became a monk but grew discontented with his slow progress toward enlightenment. Despair overcame him, and he wanted to end his life. One day, when the monks caught a snake in the fire-house, he volunteered to get rid of it. He secretly tried to make it bite him, even putting his finger in its mouth, but the snake would not bite. He told the monks it was harmless, though they disagreed. Then he took a razor intending to cut his own throat. At that very moment, as he was about to end his life, he reflected on his flawless moral conduct during his time as a monk. This reflection led to meditation, and in that instant of focused effort, he attained Arahantship. He told the monks that he had intended to cut his own throat but instead had cut off all his defilements. The monks thought he was lying and told the Buddha. The Buddha confirmed it was true and explained that in a previous life during the time of Buddha Kassapa, the snake had been this monk's slave, which is why it didn't bite him (hence he became known as the Snake-Slave Elder). The Buddha also explained that he had been discontented and on the verge of giving up even in that previous life after twenty thousand years of practice. The monks wondered if it was truly possible to attain Arahantship so quickly. The Buddha spoke this verse, explaining that it was possible for an energetic monk to achieve Arahantship even within the time it takes to lift and lower one's foot, but a lazy monk could not achieve it in a hundred years. Though the Snake-Slave Elder had been lazy for a long time, his single moment of intense, focused effort was worth more than all his previous years of half-hearted practice. That one day - indeed, that one moment - of fierce effort brought complete liberation.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṁ jīve, apassaṁ udayabbayaṁ;
Ekāhaṁ jīvitaṁ seyyo, passato udayabbayaṁ.
verses.translation: Though one should live a hundred years not understanding how all things arise and pass away, better is a single day's life if one sees how all things arise and pass away.
verses.commentary: This verse emphasizes understanding impermanence (anicca) - seeing the arising and passing away of all phenomena. A lifetime without this fundamental insight is wasted, while a single day spent perceiving the constant flux of existence is precious. Understanding impermanence is central to the Buddha's teaching because it leads to dispassion, letting go, and liberation. Udayabbaya refers specifically to seeing the arising (udaya) and dissolving (vaya) of the five aggregates (khandhas). One who truly sees how all conditioned things arise and cease understands the First Noble Truth of suffering and is on the path to liberation.

story.title: The Story of the Elder Nun Paṭācārā
story.content: Paṭācārā was the daughter of a wealthy merchant in Sāvatthī. At sixteen, she fell in love with a servant and ran away with him. They lived simply in a remote village. When pregnant, she wished to return to her parents' home to give birth, but her husband refused, fearing punishment. She left secretly, but he caught up with her. She gave birth on the journey. When pregnant again, the same happened, but this time a storm arose. Her husband went to cut wood for shelter but was bitten by a poisonous snake and died. She waited all night in the storm, protecting her children with her body, and gave birth to her second child. In the morning, she found her dead husband. Distraught, she continued toward Sāvatthī. At the flooded river Aciravatī, she was too weak to carry both children across at once. She left her older son on the bank and carried her baby across. Halfway back, a hawk swooped down on her baby. She screamed and waved, but her elder son, thinking she was calling him, jumped into the river and was swept away. Both children died. When she reached Sāvatthī, she learned her family home had been destroyed in the storm and her parents and brother had all perished. Completely insane with grief, she wandered naked. At Jetavana monastery, the Buddha addressed her as 'sister,' restoring her sanity. She covered herself and listened as the Buddha taught her about the suffering of saṁsāra. She attained Stream-entry and became a nun. Some time later, while washing her feet, she noticed how water flowed away in three stages - some drops close to her, some farther away, some still farther. This simple observation triggered deep meditation on impermanence. The Buddha, seeing her readiness with his Divine Eye, projected himself before her and spoke this verse. At its conclusion, Paṭācārā attained Arahantship. Though she had lived many years without understanding impermanence, that one day when she truly saw the arising and passing away of all phenomena was worth more than all her previous years of ignorance.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṁ jīve, apassaṁ amataṁ padaṁ;
Ekāhaṁ jīvitaṁ seyyo, passato amataṁ padaṁ.
verses.translation: Though one should live a hundred years not seeing the Deathless State, yet better is life for a single day seeing the Deathless.
verses.commentary: This verse shifts from understanding impermanence to realizing Nibbāna itself - the Deathless (amata pada). The 'Deathless State' refers to Nibbāna, which is beyond birth and death, beyond the cycle of saṁsāra. It is called 'deathless' because once attained, one is freed from repeated death and rebirth. A hundred years lived without even a glimpse of this ultimate reality is inferior to a single day in which one experiences or realizes the Deathless. This verse emphasizes that the supreme value of human life lies in the realization of Nibbāna, not in longevity or worldly achievements.

story.title: The Story of Elder Nun Kisāgotamī
story.content: Kisāgotamī was the daughter of a rich man from Sāvatthī. She was known as Kisāgotamī (Frail Gotamī) because of her slim body. She married a rich young man and a son was born to them. The boy died when he was just a toddler and Kisāgotamī was stricken with grief. Carrying the dead body of her son, she went about asking for medicine that would restore her son to life from everyone she happened to meet. People began to think that she had gone mad. But a wise man, seeing her condition, thought he should help her. He said, 'The Buddha is the person you should approach, he has the medicine you want; go to him.' Thus, she went to the Buddha and asked him to give her the medicine that would restore her son to life. The Buddha told her to get some mustard seeds from a house where there had been no death. Carrying her dead child, Kisāgotamī went from house to house with the request for mustard seeds. Everyone was willing to help her, but she could not find a single house where death had not occurred. Then, she realized that hers was not the only family that had faced death and that there were more people dead than living. As soon as she realized this, her attitude towards her dead son changed; she was no longer attached to the dead body. She left the corpse in the jungle and returned to the Buddha. The Buddha said, 'Gotamī, you thought that you alone had lost a son. As you have now realized, death comes to all beings; before their desires are fulfilled, death takes them away.' On hearing this, Kisāgotamī fully realized the impermanence, unsatisfactoriness and insubstantiality of the aggregates and attained Stream-entry. Soon afterwards, Kisāgotamī became a nun. One day, as she was lighting lamps, she saw the flames flaring up and dying out, and suddenly she clearly perceived the arising and perishing of beings. The Buddha, through supernormal power, saw her from his monastery and sent forth his radiance, appearing before her. Kisāgotamī was told to continue meditating on the impermanent nature of all beings and to strive hard to realize Nibbāna. The Buddha spoke this verse, and at its conclusion, Kisāgotamī attained Arahantship, seeing the Deathless State.

verses.pali:
Yo ca vassasataṁ jīve, apassaṁ dhammamuttamaṁ;
Ekāhaṁ jīvitaṁ seyyo, passato dhammamuttamaṁ.
verses.translation: Though one should live a hundred years not comprehending the Supreme Truth, better is a single day's life if one comprehends the Supreme Truth.
verses.commentary: This final verse of the chapter emphasizes comprehending the Dhammamuttama - the Supreme or Highest Dhamma. This refers to the Nine Transcendentals: the four stages of the path (Sotāpatti, Sakadāgāmi, Anāgāmi, and Arahantship), the four fruitions corresponding to these stages, and Nibbāna itself. These represent the supramundane teachings that lead beyond worldly existence. A hundred years lived without understanding these highest truths is worthless compared to a single day spent comprehending them. This verse concludes the chapter by emphasizing that the ultimate value of life comes from understanding and realizing the Buddha's supreme teaching.

story.title: The Story of Elder Nun Bahuputtika
story.content: Once in Sāvatthī, there lived a couple with their seven sons and seven daughters. All the children got married and the family was doing quite well. Then, the father died and the mother kept all the property without giving anything to the children. Her sons and daughters wanted the inheritance, so they said to their mother, 'What benefit do we get from our property? Can't we make it multiply? Can't we look after our mother?' They said such things again and again, so their mother thought that her children would look after her, and she finally divided up the property without leaving anything for herself. After the division of property, she first went to stay with her eldest son, but her daughter-in-law complained and said, 'She has come and stayed with us, as if she has given us two shares!' So Bahuputtika (as she came to be known - 'mother of many children') went to stay with her second son, and the same things were said. Thus, she went from one son to another, from one daughter to the next; but none of them was willing to take her on for a long period and none paid her due respect. The old lady was hurt and felt bitter against her children. She left her family and became a nun. Bahuputtika realized that she became a nun only in her old age and that she must not be negligent, but must make use of the remaining period of her life to the utmost. So, for the whole night, she meditated on the Dhamma taught by the Buddha. The Buddha, seeing her from the Jetavana monastery through supernormal power, sent forth his radiance and appeared seated in front of her. Then the Buddha said to her, 'The life of one who does not practice the Dhamma taught by me is useless, even if he were to live for a hundred years.' The Buddha spoke this verse, emphasizing that even one day spent comprehending the Supreme Dhamma - the path to liberation - is worth more than a century lived in ignorance. At the conclusion of the verse, Bahuputtika attained Arahantship, fulfilling the potential of her human life despite beginning her practice only in old age.

chapters.summary: This chapter discusses the consequences of unwholesome actions and urges practitioners to hasten toward good while restraining the mind from evil.
This chapter addresses the consequences of causing harm to others and emphasizes non-violence, compassion, and the universal desire for happiness and freedom from suffering.
This chapter reflects on the impermanence of life, the inevitability of aging and death, and the urgency of spiritual practice while one still has the opportunity.
This chapter deals with self-control, self-respect, and the importance of being one's own refuge through diligent practice and ethical conduct.
This chapter explores the nature of the world as filled with attachment and illusion, teaching that through mindfulness and right view, one can transcend worldly suffering.
This chapter praises the qualities and teachings of the Buddha, describing the path to awakening and the characteristics of those who follow the Buddha's way.
This chapter reveals the true nature of happiness beyond material possessions, teaching that genuine joy comes from freedom from hatred, health, contentment, and ultimately, Nibbāna.
This chapter explores the nature of affection and attachment, warning about the sorrow that arises from excessive attachment to loved ones and pleasant things.
This chapter addresses the destructive nature of anger and teaches the cultivation of patience, loving-kindness, and the abandonment of resentment.
Using the metaphor of rust and stains, this chapter discusses various mental impurities that hinder spiritual progress and emphasizes purification through wisdom and effort.
This chapter explores the nature of true justice and righteousness, teaching that wisdom comes not from speaking much but from living peacefully and fearlessly in accordance with truth.
This chapter provides guidance on the Noble Eightfold Path, emphasizing its role as the way to purification, the cessation of suffering, and the attainment of Nibbāna.
